Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; part of lotus flower in added red and added white above one white and one red band; exterior: painted decoration consisting of head of goose to right and part of second goose (body, wing, part of foot and beak remaining) to right, looking back; complex swastikas and rosette as filling ornament.
Producer name: Close to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Williams)
Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Lemos)
Curator's comments: Lemos describes the sherd as part of the Group of the Aphrodite Bowl, rather than as by the painter of the bowl, because the sherd displays a greater amount of variety in the filling ornaments, albeit similar to those on the Aphrodite Bowl (Lemos 1991, 74-5). According to Lemos, the geese appear to be courting. Williams explains that the painter of this chalice was probably also responsible for British Museum 1888,0601.475.g, 1924,1201.115, Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.48.1894, GR.49.1894 and probably GR.50.1894. The painter was also closely related to the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl. Whilst the sherd is decorated in the Wild Goat Style, the presence of lotus flowers as interior decoration suggests that it probably belongs to the later period of that style.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 74, p. 236, no. 151, pl. 14)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 28)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0390) (phase 2)
